steps.intro:
To ensure the security of your organization's account and regulate user access to portal features, you or any other Organization Administrator must create a user login for each member of your organization.

Tip: Customer Portal user logins not already associated with your organization's account cannot be retroactively linked to your account by the Organization Administrator or by Red Hat Customer Service or Technical Support.

When logged in, you can access User Management from any page on the Red Hat Customer Portal by clicking your name in the global user bar at the top of the page, and then User Management in the Red Hat Account Menu.

steps.title: User List
steps.intro:
The User List page lists all users associated with your account and is the starting place from which you can create new user logins.

To add individual users one at a time, click Add New User.

steps.title: Add User
steps.intro:
On the Create New User page, complete all *required fields. Be sure to assign the appropriate permissions for the user under the "Customer Portal Access Permissions" section. Checking the Organization Administrator box under "Account Roles" will give the user all the permissions listed in the Customer Portal Access Permissions section.

Repeat this process for each user you want to add.

steps.title: Bulk User Creation
steps.intro: To add a larger number of users at once, click Upload new users on the User List page.

steps.title: Bulk User Upload
steps.intro:
Here, you can upload users via a .csv file.

Download and complete the .csv template to so that the data is properly structured, and then upload the file.

Tip: You cannot set users as Organization Administrators via .csv upload. However, to assign the OA role in bulk once the users are created, go back to the "User List" page, select the appropriate users from the list, click "Edit" and check "Organization Administrator." For more info on bulk editing see this instructional video.

Red Hat recommends that you create a unique user login for every individual within your organization involved the Red Hat product lifecycle - from planning and design all the way through production maintenance and support. For more information on the benefits of assigning individual user logins, reference this knowledge article.

Tip: In order to effectively and efficiently communicate with each member of your organization, a good best practice is to perform user management maintenance once every quarter.
